ground_truth: Don Birnam, dressed in a light summer suit, paces up and down the lobby, keeping an eye on the elevator doors. He carries a florist's box under his arm and walks toward a circular settee, where he sits down, places the flower box next to him, and adjusts his tie, still watching the elevators. On the other side of the settee is a middle-aged couple, Mr. and Mrs. St. James. Although they can't see each other, Don overhears their conversation and eventually realizes they are Helen's parents. Mr. St. James wears a linen suit and a yellowing panama hat, while Mrs. St. James is a cheerful woman with glasses pinned to her dress. Feeling uncomfortable, Don leans his head against the back of the settee. Mr. St. James fumes slightly while Mrs. St. James laughs comfortably. Don then picks up the florist's box, rises, and moves away toward some potted palms for security, from where he looks back. Helen arrives through a revolving door in a new spring suit, sees her parents, and greets them with some conversation about Don arriving shortly. Don, undecided, locates the public phone booths and steps into one, depositing a nickel to dial the number of the Hotel Manhattan. Watching through the glass door of the booth, he sees Helen rise and move to the house phones, where she speaks into a phone and then hangs up with a crestfallen expression. As she returns to her parents, she appears to begin explaining. Meanwhile, Don quietly emerges with the florist's box and exits through a side door. In a dim foreground, the scene shifts to a small table and the vague outline of Don lying on a couch. A key turns in the lock, and Wick enters, finding an empty bottle on the floor and a half-filled glass in Don's hand. Wick turns on the entrance hall light, casually hangs his hat on a hook, and enters the living room, noticing Don's presence. Don covers his face with his arm. Wick, wearing a hat and carrying a briefcase, throws it into a chair and turns off the light.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, attired in a light summer ensemble, strides up and down the foyer, keeping an eye on the lift portals. He carries a florist's container under his arm and walks toward a circular sofa, where he sits down, places the blossom container next to him, and adjusts his cravat, still watching the lifts. On the other side of the sofa is a middle-aged duo, Mr. and Mrs. St. James. Although they can't see each other, Don overhears their dialogue and eventually realizes they are Helen's progenitors. Mr. St. James wears a linen ensemble and a yellowing straw hat, while Mrs. St. James is a cheerful woman with spectacles pinned to her garment. Feeling uncomfortable, Don leans his head against the back of the sofa. Mr. St. James fumes slightly while Mrs. St. James laughs comfortably. Don then picks up the florist's container, rises, and moves away toward some potted palms for security, from where he looks back. Helen arrives through a revolving door in a new spring ensemble, sees her progenitors, and greets them with some dialogue about Don arriving shortly. Don, undecided, locates the public telephone booths and steps into one, depositing a nickel to dial the number of the Hotel Manhattan. Watching through the glass door of the cubicle, he sees Helen rise and move to the house telephones, where she speaks into a telephone and then hangs up with a crestfallen expression. As she returns to her progenitors, she appears to begin explaining. Meanwhile, Don quietly emerges with the florist's container and exits through a side door. In a dim foreground, the scene shifts to a small table and the vague outline of Don lying on a couch. A key turns in the lock, and Wick enters, finding an empty bottle on the floor and a half-filled goblet in Don's hand. Wick turns on the entrance hall light, casually hangs his hat on a peg, and enters the living room, noticing Don's presence. Don covers his face with his arm. Wick, wearing a hat and carrying a briefcase, throws it into a chair and turns off the light.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, dressed in a light summer suit, paces up and down the lobby, keeping an eye on the elevator doors. A florist's box is carried under his arm by him, and he walks toward a circular settee, where he sits down, places the flower box next to him, and adjusts his tie, still watching the elevators. On the other side of the settee is a middle-aged couple, Mr. and Mrs. St. James. Although they can't see each other, a conversation is overheard by Don, and he eventually realizes they are Helen's parents. A linen suit and a yellowing panama hat are worn by Mr. St. James, while Mrs. St. James is a cheerful woman with glasses pinned to her dress. Feeling uncomfortable, the back of the settee is leaned against by Don with his head. A slight fuming is done by Mr. St. James while Mrs. St. James comfortably laughs. The florist's box is then picked up by Don, who rises and moves away toward some potted palms for security, from where a look back is given by him. Through a revolving door, Helen arrives in a new spring suit, sees her parents, and greets them with some conversation about Don arriving shortly. Undecided, Don locates the public phone booths and steps into one, depositing a nickel to dial the number of the Hotel Manhattan. Watching through the glass door of the booth, Helen is seen by him as she rises and moves to the house phones, where she speaks into a phone and then hangs up with a crestfallen expression. As she returns to her parents, an explanation appears to be begun by her. Meanwhile, Don quietly emerges with the florist's box and exits through a side door. In a dim foreground, the scene shifts to a small table and the vague outline of Don lying on a couch. In the lock, a key is turned, and the entrance is made by Wick, finding an empty bottle on the floor and a half-filled glass in Don's hand. The entrance hall light is turned on by Wick, who casually hangs his hat on a hook and enters the living room, noticing Don's presence. Don covers his face with his arm. A briefcase is carried by Wick, who throws it into a chair and turns off the light.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, in a light summer suit, paces the lobby, watching the elevator doors. Holding a florist's box, he sits on a circular settee, adjusting his tie while observing the elevators. Across from him, a middle-aged couple, Mr. and Mrs. St. James, chat; Don realizes they are Helen's parents. Mr. St. James wears a linen suit and a yellowing panama hat, while the cheerful Mrs. St. James has glasses pinned to her dress. Feeling uneasy, Don leans back against the settee. Mr. St. James frowns slightly, and Mrs. St. James laughs. Don then picks up the florist's box and moves toward potted palms, watching. Helen arrives in a new spring suit, greets her parents, and talks about Don arriving soon. Indecisive, Don finds a public phone booth, dials Hotel Manhattan, and watches Helen speak on the house phone, appearing dejected afterward. She seems to explain to her parents as Don quietly exits through a side door with the florist's box. The scene shifts to Don lying on a couch by a small table in dim light. Wick enters, finding an empty bottle and a half-filled glass in Don's hand. Wick turns on the light, hangs his hat, enters the living room, and sees Don, who covers his face with his arm. Wick, with a hat and briefcase, throws it into a chair and turns off the light.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, in a light summer suit, paces the lobby, watching the elevator doors with a florist's box under his arm. He sits by a circular settee, places the box beside him, and adjusts his tie, still eyeing the elevators. Opposite, a middle-aged couple, Mr. and Mrs. St. James, converse; Don realizes they are Helen's parents. Mr. St. James wears a linen suit and yellowing panama hat, while Mrs. St. James is cheerful with glasses pinned to her dress. Uncomfortable, Don leans back, hearing Mr. St. James fume while Mrs. St. James laughs. Don then picks up his box, moves toward the potted palms for privacy, and watches. Helen enters in a new spring suit, greets her parents, and mentions Don's arrival. Indecisive, Don finds a phone booth, dials the Hotel Manhattan, and watches Helen at the house phones. She hangs up, looking crestfallen, and returns to her parents to explain. Don quietly exits with the florist's box through a side door. The scene shifts to a dim room with Don lying on a couch. Wick enters, finds an empty bottle, notices Don with a half-filled glass, turns on the light, hangs his hat, enters the living room, and sees Don cover his face. Wick, with a hat and briefcase, throws it into a chair and turns off the light.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, attired in a light and airy summer suit, paces nervously up and down the spacious lobby, vigilantly keeping his eye on the elevator doors. Under his arm, he carries a florist's box, which he holds securely. Feeling a need to sit, he walks over toward a circular settee, where he carefully takes a seat, placing the flower box next to him on the seat cushion, and adjusts his tie while his gaze remains fixed on the elevators. Seated on the opposite side of the settee is a middle-aged couple, who are Mr. and Mrs. St. James. Although unable to see each other due to their seating positions, Don listens in on their conversation and gradually realizes that they are Helen's parents. Mr. St. James is dressed in a linen suit paired with a slightly yellowing panama hat, while Mrs. St. James possesses a cheerful demeanor, with glasses neatly pinned to her dress. Feeling somewhat uncomfortable, Don leans his head back against the settee's backrest. While Mr. St. James appears slightly agitated, Mrs. St. James laughs in a comfortable manner. Shortly after, Don reaches for the florist's box, stands up, and moves away toward a cluster of potted palms for a sense of security, from where he steals a glance back. Helen makes her entrance through the revolving door, dressed in a new and fresh spring suit, notices her parents, and greets them with a conversation that includes mentioning Don’s expected arrival shortly. Feeling uncertain, Don heads over to where the public phone booths are located and steps into one, depositing a nickel to dial the number of the Hotel Manhattan. Through the glass door of the phone booth, he observes Helen as she rises and moves over to the house phones, where she speaks into the receiver and then hangs up, her expression notably crestfallen. As she returns to her parents, she seems to be beginning some sort of explanation. Meanwhile, Don discreetly emerges, still holding the florist's box, and discreetly exits through a side door. In the dimly lit foreground, the scene transitions to a small table and the faint outline of Don lying on a couch. A key turns in the lock, and Wick enters, finding an empty bottle on the floor alongside a half-filled glass in Don's hand. Wick switches on the entrance hall light, casually hangs his hat on a nearby hook, and steps into the living room, noticing Don's presence. Don uses his arm to cover his face. Wick, still wearing a hat and carrying a briefcase, tosses it into an armchair and turns off the light.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, dressed in a light and breezy summer suit that seemed perfect for the warm weather, paces nervously back and forth across the expansive lobby. His eyes are intently focused on the elevator doors as he moves, vigilantly watching them. Tucked securely under his arm, he carries a florist's box, holding it tightly as if afraid it might slip away. Feeling the urge to rest for a moment, he makes his way over to a circular settee, where he carefully takes a seat, placing the flower box gently beside him on the seat cushion. As he settles in, he adjusts his tie with meticulous care while his gaze remains unwaveringly fixed on the nearby elevators. Seated on the opposite side of the settee is a middle-aged couple, who are none other than Mr. and Mrs. St. James. Due to their seating positions, they are unable to see one another, but Don can hear their conversation, and he gradually pieces together the realization that they are, in fact, Helen's parents. Mr. St. James is clad in a linen suit, accompanied by a slightly yellowing panama hat that adds a touch of character to his ensemble, while Mrs. St. James exudes a cheerful demeanor, with her glasses neatly pinned to her dress as if they are an integral part of her attire. Feeling somewhat uncomfortable with the situation, Don leans his head back against the settee's backrest, trying to ease his tension. Mr. St. James appears slightly agitated, shifting in his seat, while Mrs. St. James lets out a laugh that suggests she is quite at ease. Not long after, Don reaches for the florist's box, stands up with determination, and discreetly moves toward a cluster of potted palms, seeking a sense of security and a brief escape from the situation. From this position, he steals a glance back toward the settee. Helen then makes her entrance through the revolving door, clad in a brand new and fresh spring suit, exuding a sense of renewal. She immediately notices her parents and greets them warmly, engaging in a conversation that includes the mention of Don’s expected arrival shortly. Feeling uncertain and hesitant, Don makes his way over to the area where the public phone booths are located. He steps into one of the booths, carefully depositing a nickel into the slot to dial the number of the Hotel Manhattan. Through the booth's glass door, he observes Helen as she rises from her seat and moves over to the house phones. She speaks into the receiver for a brief moment before hanging up, her expression turning notably crestfallen. As she returns to her parents, she seems to be beginning some sort of explanation, possibly related to Don. Meanwhile, Don discreetly emerges from the booth, still clutching the florist's box, and quietly exits through a side door, seeking to avoid any confrontation. In the dimly lit foreground, the scene shifts to a small table and the faint outline of Don lying wearily on a couch. A key turns audibly in the lock, and Wick enters the room, quickly spotting an empty bottle on the floor alongside a half-filled glass in Don's hand. Wick switches on the entrance hall light, casually hanging his hat on a nearby hook before stepping into the living room, where he notices Don's presence on the couch. Don, feeling exposed, uses his arm to cover his face. Wick, still wearing his hat and carrying a briefcase, nonchalantly tosses it into an armchair and proceeds to turn off the light.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, clad in a light summer suit, nervously paces back and forth in the hotel lobby, his eyes consistently darting towards the elevator doors as he waits anxiously. Under his arm, he clutches a florist's box, carefully maintaining its position as he strides purposefully over to a circular settee. Upon reaching the settee, he lowers himself onto it with a sense of anticipation and places the flower box gently next to him. Adjusting his tie in a habitual manner, his gaze remains fixed on the elevator doors, revealing his distracted state of mind. Opposite him on the settee sit Mr. and Mrs. St. James, a middle-aged couple engaged in a conversation that filters into Don's consciousness. Despite being partially hidden from their view, Don strains to listen, gradually piecing together from their words that they are the parents of Helen. Mr. St. James, distinguished in a linen suit and a worn panama hat, exudes a slight aura of irritation, while Mrs. St. James, with glasses affixed to her dress, radiates a cheerful energy through her laughter. Feeling a growing discomfort, Don leans his head back against the settee, seeking a momentary reprieve amidst the couple's dynamic. When faced with the discomfort of the situation, he decides to take action; he picks up the florist's box, rises from his seat, and moves cautiously away towards a cluster of potted palms, seeking a semblance of security and partial concealment. From this leafy refuge, he casts a backward glance towards the lobby. It is then that Helen appears, gracefully entering through the revolving door in a fresh spring suit, her presence immediately engaging her parents in a light-hearted exchange about Don's impending arrival. As Don wrestles internally with his next move, he spots the public phone booths nearby, prompting him to head over, enter one, and deposit a nickel into the machine with a calculated motion. He dials the number for the Hotel Manhattan, all the while observing through the booth's glass door as Helen rises and approaches the house phones with an air of expectation. She speaks into the phone with hopeful intent but then hangs up, her expression shifting to one of disappointment that she takes back to her parents, likely beginning to explain the situation as Don watches on. Seizing the moment, Don quietly emerges from the phone booth, the florist's box once again under his arm, and stealthily exits through a discreet side door. The setting then transitions subtly to a dim foreground, revealing a small table near the shadowy outline of Don reclined on a couch. The stillness is broken by the sound of a key turning in the lock, and Wick enters the scene, immediately noting the empty bottle on the floor and the half-filled glass poised in Don's hand. Wick moves with an air of familiarity, as he turns on the entrance hall light, hangs his hat on a hook with casual ease, and steps into the living room, acknowledging Don's presence with a silent observation. Don, sensing Wick's presence, shields his face with his arm, seeking solace in the darkness. Meanwhile, Wick, still wearing his hat, tosses his briefcase into a nearby chair and, with a final, decisive motion, turns off the light, leaving the dim outlines of the room to envelop them once more.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, dressed in a light summer suit, paces the lobby while keeping an eye on the elevator doors, holding a florist's box under his arm. He sits on a circular settee, adjusting his tie as he keeps watch. Nearby, Mr. and Mrs. St. James, unaware of Don's presence, engage in a conversation that Don eavesdrops on, eventually recognizing them as Helen's parents. Feeling uneasy, Don leans back, listening as Mr. St. James voices irritation and Mrs. St. James laughs. Don then discreetly moves toward potted palms for some privacy, observing as Helen arrives in a new spring suit. She greets her parents, mentioning Don is expected soon. Feeling conflicted, Don locates a phone booth, dials the Hotel Manhattan, and observes Helen's crestfallen expression after using the house phone. As she returns to her parents, appearing to explain, Don quietly leaves with the florist's box through a side door. The scene shifts to a dimly lit room where Don lies on a couch, holding a half-filled glass. Wick enters, finding an empty bottle on the floor, hangs his hat, and notices Don, who shields his face with his arm. Wick, still dressed in his hat and carrying a briefcase, casually throws it into a chair and turns off the light.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, dressed in a light summer suit that complements the warm, bustling atmosphere of New York City, paces up and down the lobby of a midtown hotel, keeping an eye on the elevator doors with a sense of anticipation. He carries a florist's box under his arm, a common gesture of romance or apology in the city, and walks toward a circular settee, a style of seating often found in hotel lobbies designed for social interaction, where he sits down, places the flower box next to him, and adjusts his tie with a practiced hand, still watching the elevators. Across from him sits a middle-aged couple, Mr. and Mrs. St. James, visiting from a small town in upstate New York. Although they can't see each other, Don overhears their conversation and eventually realizes they are Helen's parents, who have traveled to the city for a rare visit. Mr. St. James wears a linen suit and a yellowing panama hat, a style that hints at his age and traditionalist nature, while Mrs. St. James is a cheerful woman with glasses pinned to her dress, reminiscent of the practical fashion of the 1940s. Feeling uncomfortable, Don leans his head against the back of the settee, a gesture that suggests his growing anxiety. Mr. St. James fumes slightly, displaying a temperament typical of a protective father, while Mrs. St. James laughs comfortably, perhaps trying to diffuse the tension. Don then picks up the florist's box, rises, and moves away toward some potted palms, a standard decorative feature in such hotels that offer a semblance of privacy, from where he looks back. Helen arrives through a revolving door in a new spring suit, indicative of her fashionable sensibilities and the season, sees her parents, and greets them with some conversation about Don arriving shortly, maintaining the veneer of normality. Don, undecided about facing Helen, locates the public phone booths, which are a staple of the era's communication, and steps into one, depositing a nickel to dial the number of the Hotel Manhattan, a popular establishment known for discretion. Watching through the glass door of the booth, he sees Helen rise and move to the house phones, where she speaks into a phone, perhaps reaching out to him, and then hangs up with a crestfallen expression, signaling her disappointment. As she returns to her parents, she appears to begin explaining, perhaps preempting their questions about Don's delay. Meanwhile, Don quietly emerges with the florist's box and exits through a side door, possibly seeking solitude. In a dim foreground, the scene shifts to a small table and the vague outline of Don lying on a couch, a common place for reflection or escape. A key turns in the lock, and Wick enters, finding an empty bottle on the floor and a half-filled glass in Don's hand, evidence of Don's struggle with alcohol. Wick, Don's concerned friend, turns on the entrance hall light, casually hangs his hat on a hook, reflecting his familiarity with the place, and enters the living room, noticing Don's presence. Don covers his face with his arm, an act of shame or concealment. Wick, wearing a hat and carrying a briefcase, suggesting his role as a supportive but pragmatic figure, throws it into a chair and turns off the light, perhaps to offer Don quiet solidarity.

On the other side of the settee is a middleaged couple Mr and Mrs St James. Although they cannot see each other Don overhears their conversation and eventually realizes they are Helen's parents. Mr St James wears a linen suit and a yellowing panama hat while Mrs St James is a cheerful woman with glasses pinned to her dress. Wick turns on the entrance hall. light casually hangs his hat on a hook and enters the living room. noticing Don's presence. Don covers his face with his arm. Wick wearing a hat and carrying a briefcase throws it into a chair and turns off the light.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Don Birnam dressed in a light summer suit paces up and down the lobby keeping an eye on the elevator doors. He carries a florist's box under his arm and walks toward a circular settee where he sits down places the flower box next to him and adjusts his tie still watching the elevators. Don covers his face with his arm. Wick wearing a hat and carrying a briefcase throws it into a chair and turns off the light.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: A pigeon, dressed in a light summer suit, paces up and down the lobby, keeping an eye on the elevator doors. It carries a florist's box under its wing and walks toward a circular settee, where it sits down, places the flower box next to it, and adjusts its tie, still watching the elevators. On the other side of the settee is a middle-aged squirrel, Mr. and Mrs. St. James. Although they can't see each other, the pigeon overhears their conversation and eventually realizes they are Helen's parents. Mr. St. James wears a linen suit and a yellowing panama hat, while Mrs. St. James is a cheerful squirrel with glasses pinned to her dress. Feeling uncomfortable, the pigeon leans its head against the back of the settee. Mr. St. James fumes slightly while Mrs. St. James laughs comfortably. The pigeon then picks up the florist's box, rises, and moves away toward some potted palms for security, from where it looks back. A rabbit arrives through a revolving door in a new spring suit, sees its parents, and greets them with some conversation about the pigeon arriving shortly. The pigeon, undecided, locates the public phone booths and steps into one, depositing a nickel to dial the number of the Hotel Manhattan. Watching through the glass door of the booth, it sees the rabbit rise and move to the house phones, where it speaks into a phone and then hangs up with a crestfallen expression. As it returns to its parents, it appears to begin explaining. Meanwhile, the pigeon quietly emerges with the florist's box and exits through a side door. In a dim foreground, the scene shifts to a small table and the vague outline of the pigeon lying on a couch. A key turns in the lock, and a tortoise enters, finding an empty bottle on the floor and a half-filled glass in the pigeon's hand. The tortoise turns on the entrance hall light, casually hangs its hat on a hook, and enters the living room, noticing the pigeon's presence. The pigeon covers its face with its wing. The tortoise, wearing a hat and carrying a briefcase, throws it into a chair and turns off the light.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, dressed in a light summer suit, paces up and down the arcade, keeping an eye on the escalator doors. He carries a violin case under his arm and walks toward a circular fountain, where he sits down, places the instrument case next to him, and adjusts his cufflinks, still watching the escalators. On the other side of the fountain is a middle-aged couple, Mr. and Mrs. St. James. Although they can't see each other, Don overhears their conversation and eventually realizes they are Helen's parents. Mr. St. James wears a denim jacket and a weathered cowboy hat, while Mrs. St. James is a cheerful woman with earrings pinned to her blouse. Feeling uncomfortable, Don leans his head against the back of the fountain. Mr. St. James fumes slightly while Mrs. St. James laughs comfortably. Don then picks up the violin case, rises, and moves away toward some potted ferns for security, from where he looks back. Helen arrives through a sliding door in a new autumn jacket, sees her parents, and greets them with some conversation about Don arriving shortly. Don, undecided, locates the public vending machines and steps into one, depositing a quarter to dial the number of the Hotel Manhattan. Watching through the glass panel of the machine, he sees Helen rise and move to the house intercom, where she speaks into a device and then hangs up with a crestfallen expression. As she returns to her parents, she appears to begin explaining. Meanwhile, Don quietly emerges with the violin case and exits through a side gate. In a dim foreground, the scene shifts to a small pedestal and the vague outline of Don lying on a hammock. A key turns in the lock, and Wick enters, finding an empty teacup on the floor and a half-filled mug in Don's hand. Wick turns on the entrance hall lamp, casually hangs his helmet on a peg, and enters the living room, noticing Don's presence. Don covers his face with his arm. Wick, wearing a helmet and carrying a backpack, throws it into a stool and turns off the lamp.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, dressed in a light summer suit, strolls through the lobby, glancing at the elevator doors. He balances a florist's box under his arm and heads toward a circular settee, where he lays down, places the flower box beside him, and ruffles his tie, still observing the elevators. On the other side of the settee is a middle-aged couple, Mr. and Mrs. St. James. Although they can't see each other, Don listens in on their conversation and eventually perceives they are Helen's parents. Mr. St. James sports a linen suit and a yellowing Panama hat, while Mrs. St. James is a cheerful woman with glasses pinned to her dress. Feeling uneasy, Don rests his head against the back of the settee. Mr. St. James grumbles slightly while Mrs. St. James chuckles comfortably. Don then retrieves the florist's box, stands, and wanders over to some potted palms for security, from where he peers back. Helen enters through a revolving door in a new spring suit, notices her parents, and acknowledges them with some conversation about Don appearing shortly. Don, hesitating, identifies the public phone booths and slips into one, inserting a nickel to dial the number of the Hotel Manhattan. Watching through the glass door of the booth, he observes Helen stand and approach the house phones, where she talks into a phone and then places it down with a disheartened expression. As she returns to her parents, she seems to start elaborating. Meanwhile, Don discreetly appears with the florist's box and leaves through a side door. In a dim foreground, the scene transitions to a small table and the faint outline of Don reclining on a couch. A key turns in the lock, and Wick arrives, spotting an empty bottle on the floor and a half-filled glass in Don's hand. Wick switches on the entrance hall light, casually drapes his hat on a hook, and steps into the living room, noticing Don's presence. Don shields his face with his arm. Wick, wearing a hat and carrying a briefcase, flings it into a chair and dims the light.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Billy Pickett, dressed in a light autumn jacket, strolls back and forth the kitchen, keeping an eye on the garage doors. He carries a magician's hat under his arm and walks toward a square hammock, where he sits down, places the magic hat next to him, and adjusts his scarf, still watching the garages. On the other side of the hammock is a young troupe, Mr. and Mrs. Windlass. Although they can't see each other, Billy overhears their conversation and eventually realizes they are Charlie's friends. Mr. Windlass wears a denim jacket and a worn beret, while Mrs. Windlass is a serious woman with a hood pinned to her coat. Feeling uncomfortable, Billy leans his head against the back of the hammock. Mr. Windlass snorts slightly while Mrs. Windlass chuckles dryly. Billy then picks up the magician's hat, rises, and moves away toward some hanging lanterns for security, from where he looks back. Charlie enters through a sliding window in a faded winter coat, sees his friends, and greets them with some conversation about Billy arriving shortly. Billy, undecided, locates the public newsstands and steps into one, depositing a quarter to dial the number of the Circus Marquis. Watching through the glass window of the stand, he sees Charlie rise and move to the barn doors, where he speaks into a handheld radio and then puts it away with a puzzled expression. As he returns to his friends, he appears to begin explaining. Meanwhile, Billy quietly emerges with the magician's hat and exits through a hidden passage. In a shadowy foreground, the scene shifts to a large chair and the vague outline of Billy sprawled on a futon. A latch turns in the gate, and Gus enters, finding an empty can on the carpet and a half-filled pitcher in Billy's hand. Gus turns on the kitchen counter light, casually hangs his bracelet on a nail, and enters the study, noticing Billy's presence. Billy covers his face with his hat. Gus, wearing a bracelet and carrying a folder, throws it into a basket and turns off the light.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Max Harper, clad in a light autumn blazer, shuffles back and forth in the atrium, glancing at the stairway entrance. He clutches a painter's kit under his arm and strides toward a circular armchair, where he perches, sets the kit beside him, and straightens his watch, still gazing at the stairway. On the opposite side of the armchair is an elderly pair, Mr. and Mrs. Thompson. Although they fail to see each other, Max eavesdrops on their chat and gradually figures out they are Emily's relatives. Mr. Thompson sports a denim jacket and a faded straw hat, while Mrs. Thompson is a joyful woman with a scarf pinned to her blouse. Feeling edgy, Max tilts his head against the back of the armchair. Mr. Thompson grumbles a bit while Mrs. Thompson chuckles gently. Max then grabs the painter's kit, stands up, and ambles toward some decorative ferns for refuge, from where he glances back. Emily enters through an automatic door in a fresh autumn jacket, spots her relatives, and approaches them with some talk about Max arriving soon. Max, wavering, discovers the public restrooms and steps into one, donates a penny to dial the number of the Café Royale. Peering through the restroom's glazed door, he watches Emily stand and proceed to the concierge desk, where she whispers into a phone and then disconnects with a disappointed demeanor. As she returns to her relatives, she seems to start explaining. Meanwhile, Max quietly slips out with the painter's kit and exits through a hidden passageway. In a shadowy foreground, the scene transitions to a small desk and the faint outline of Max reclining on a recliner. A latch clicks in the lock, and Tom arrives, spotting a broken easel on the floor and a half-used canvas in Max's grip. Tom flicks on the corridor lamp, leisurely places his scarf on a rack, and steps into the lounge, noting Max’s presence. Max hides his eyes with his hand. Tom, donning a scarf and holding a backpack, tosses it into a chair and douses the light.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, dressed in a light summer outfit, ambles up and down the atrium, keeping an eye on the escalator doors. He carries a painter's canvas under his arm and strides toward a rectangular ottoman, where he reclines, places the art canvas beside him, and adjusts his scarf, still observing the escalators. On the opposite side of the ottoman is a middle-aged duo, Mr. and Mrs. St. James. Although they can’t see each other, Don listens to their dialogue and eventually deduces they are Helen's relatives. Mr. St. James sports a woolen outfit and a tattered beret, while Mrs. St. James is a cheerful woman with a brooch pinned to her cardigan. Feeling uneasy, Don tilts his head against the back of the ottoman. Mr. St. James scowls slightly while Mrs. St. James chuckles heartily. Don then picks up the painter's canvas, stands, and glides away toward some woven baskets for comfort, from where he glances back. Helen arrives through a swinging door in a fresh autumn dress, spots her relatives, and greets them with some chatter about Don arriving soon. Don, hesitant, discovers the public writing desks and steps into one, depositing a dime to jot down the address of the Hotel Manhattan. Watching through the glass partition of the desk, he sees Helen rise and move to the service desk, where she murmurs into a phone and then hangs up with a downcast look. As she returns to her relatives, she seems to begin explaining. Meanwhile, Don quietly steps out with the painter's canvas and slips out through a hidden passage. In a dim backdrop, the scene shifts to a small stool and the vague outline of Don sprawled on a futon. A handle turns in the door, and Wick enters, finding an empty mug on the table and a half-filled tumbler in Don's grasp. Wick flips on the corridor lamp, casually hangs his cap on a peg, and steps into the sitting room, noticing Don’s form. Don conceals his face with his hand. Wick, donning a cap and carrying a satchel, flings it into a seat and extinguishes the lamp.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Rex Twinkleton, dressed in a heavy winter coat, circles around the marketplace, glancing at the escalator handles. He carries a fisherman's net over his shoulder and shuffles toward a rectangular hammock, where he lies down, places the fishing net beside him, and adjusts his scarf, still observing the escalators. On the opposite side of the hammock is a teenage duo, Mr. and Mrs. McFluff. Although they can't smell each other, Rex eavesdrops on their dialogue and eventually concludes they are Norah's siblings. Mr. McFluff wears a denim jacket and a fading baseball cap, while Mrs. McFluff is a grumpy individual with mittens pinned to her coat. Feeling awkward, Rex leans his elbow against the edge of the hammock. Mr. McFluff grumbles slightly while Mrs. McFluff giggles softly. Rex then grabs the fisherman's net, stands, and shuffles away toward some fake cacti for peace of mind, from where he glances back. Norah arrives through a sliding gate in an old autumn jacket, spots her siblings, and acknowledges them with some talk about Rex appearing imminently. Rex, hesitating, locates the snack vending machines and steps into one, depositing a dime to request the location of the Oasis Arcade. Observing through the plastic window of the machine, he notices Norah stand and migrate to the piano wires, where she sings into a loudspeaker and then unplugs it with a thrilled expression. As she returns to her siblings, she seems to commence declaring. Meanwhile, Rex silently emerges with the fisherman's net and slips away through a trap door. In a shadowy backdrop, the scene shifts to a round carpet and the faint shape of Rex reclining on a recliner. A card swipes in the slot, and Rude enters, identifying a shattered vase on the shelf and a half-eaten sandwich in Rex’s grasp. Rude flicks on the kitchen stove light, lazily tosses his cap onto a hatstand, and enters the dining hallway, remarking upon Rex’s existence. Rex shades his eyes with his elbow. Rude, wearing a beanie and clutching a satchel, flings it onto a sofa and extinguishes the lamp.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Don Birnam, in a summer suit, anxiously watches elevator doors in a lobby and sits by a middle-aged couple, Mr. and Mrs. St. James, without realizing they are Helen's parents. Feeling awkward, Don soon moves away with a florist's box to a spot near potted palms. Helen arrives, greets her parents, and talks about Don, who hesitantly uses a phone booth. Observing Helen become crestfallen after a phone call, Don quietly exits through a side door. The scene shifts to a dimly lit room where Don lies on a couch with an empty bottle. Wick, entering and switching on the light, notices Don's state and turns off the light again.
